awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Kinetics and Mechanism of Restructuring of Atmospheric Soot and Associated Impact on Light Absorption
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanoparticulate atmospheric soot particles are complex in their shape, size and chemical composition. They can be variably observed as fractal aggregates composed of elemental carbon (EC- in graphitic or graphene structures), or organic carbon compounds (OC - hydrocarbons with oxidized or other attached heteroatom moieties). Other aerosol materials potentially embed or enmesh, in either internal or external mixing states, such soot particles as they age in the ambient atmosphere. Our limited knowledge of relationships between soot mixing state, soot morphology, and soot optical properties, remains a major source of uncertainty in evaluating the optical and radiative contribution of carbonaceous aerosols to direct radiative) climate forcing. Researchers will undertake a series of combined laboratory and computational studies to better characterize the formation of soot particles with different mixing states, and to investigate associated structural and optical properties in relation to the particle initial state and aerosol aging. 

Mixing states and morphology of soot aggregates will be determined from a combination of mass-mobility measurements and environmental scanning electron microscopy imaging. Optical calculations constrained by the experimentally measured mixing states and morphologies will provide a closure with directly determined light absorption and scattering by this range of carbonaceous soot.

One broader impact of this work will be the promotion of collaboration between faculty at a PhD-granting and a primarily undergraduate teaching university.

por.por_cntn:
Soot particles are formed from incomplete combustion of fossil fuels and biomass and may be emitted into the atmosphere from wild fires or human activities such as diesel engine and passenger car emissions. Soot particles are complex in their shape, size and chemical composition. Soot freshly emitted from the source is often an irregularly shaped aggregate of randomly connected small, spherical monomers made of elemental carbon. Such irregular and randomly branched shape of fresh soot is often referred as a fractal shape.

Various organic compounds in the atmosphere will start interact with soot once it is emitted into the air and form a layer of coating on the fresh soot, normally referred as the aging process. The aging of soot may or may change the shape of soot particles into a more spherical and compacted one. Our limited knowledge on how the soot aging may change the shape of soot particles is currently limiting our understanding on the optical properties of soot, including the light scattering and absorption of soot particles. This limitation remains a major source of uncertainties in evaluating the contribution of soot to the climate change due to the absorption and scattering of the sun light.

In this project generously sponsored by the National Science Foundation, we performed a series of laboratory experiments to understand how different coating materials on soot may change the shape of soot particles. We discovered that the effect of coating materials on soot shape change during aging depends largely on how volatile the coating materials is. We then conducted laboratory and computational studies to better characterize how different shapes and coatings can change the light absorption and scattering of soot particles. Our results therefore will further our understanding on how the aging of soot may contribute to the climate change.

Our studies have yielded open-source software packages, publications on scientific journals and presentations at regional and national professional conferences. During this projects, a cohort of undergraduate students from primarily undergraduate institutions were sponsored to travel to a research intensive university and to participate in laboratory and computational research. These undergraduate students were trained on research methodology and techniques that will benefit their future careers in STEM field. Some of the students have advanced into graduate programs pursuing advanced degrees in STEM fields.
